name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Wallops - Range Mission Support
description:
Assist with Project Management for missions projects including providing support documentation for flight preparations and analysis, support plans, Standard Operating Procedures (SOP's) and flight area surveys, develop forecast and mission schedules, develop mission presentations in support of sounding rockets and ELV missions.

Deliverables include: Project Charter, Project Forecast, Instrumentation Support Briefing, Project Support Plan, Operations Directive.

No experience necessary, must be able to use Microsoft products.

Only thing required is a good work attitude and be willing to learn.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Wallops Flight Facility in Wallops Island, VA.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Goddard Space Flight Center (GSFC) has partnered with the National Space Club & Foundation to offer a six-week program for High School students within a 50 mile radius of GSFC Greenbelt or Wallops Flight Facility (WFF). The Space Club program provides students an in-person educational opportunity at NASA. Participants will be required to be onsite from June 30 - August 8, working five days per week, without any time off. Students will not work on July 4, which is a federal holiday.

For the list of all Summer 2025 Space Club Scholars projects, visit https://www.nasa.gov/goddard/stem/space-club-scholars-program/

To be eligible for this program, students must meet the following criteria:
- At time of application: 10, 11, 12 grade and in good standing; Must have completed Sophomore year in high school by the starting date of the program;
- Must be a U.S. citizen;
- Must live and maintain a permanent residence within commuting distance (50 miles) of the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, MD, or the NASA Wallops Flight Facility, Wallops Island, VA;
- Minimum 3.0 GPA (unweighted) on a 4.0 scale
- Must be 16 years of age by June 30, 2025. For students that are 15 at time of application see NOTE below.

**************** NOTE if 15 Years Old at Time of Application******************
The Space Club Scholars program is open to students who are 16 by the start of the program on June 30, 2025. Due to a system limitation, students who are 15 at time of application are restricted from submitting applications directly to the individual project(s). Students who are 15 may have two options.

Option 1. If you are 15 but will turn 16 before the application deadline, March 15, 11:59 p.m., you can wait to apply to each project until you turn 16. This is the preferred option; however, you may also apply with Option 2. For Option 1, you will upload a current transcript and resume to your profile and submit an application to every project that you are interested. See the full list of projects at this website: https://www.nasa.gov/goddard/stem/space-club-scholars-program/

Option 2. If you are 15 but will turn 16 between March 16-June 30, then this is your only option to apply for the Space Club program. For Option 2, you will upload a current transcript, resume, and list of projects you are interested in to the following opportunity, "Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt & Wallops": https://stemgateway.nasa.gov/s/course-offering/a0BSJ000001euED/.

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - Remote Sensing and Aerosol Retrieval
description:
Aerosols, such as particulate pollution, dust, smoke and sea salt, play important roles in Earth's radiative balance, cloud and precipitation formation, fertilization of ecosystems, air quality and human health. Retrieval of aerosol parameters from space-based spectral radiometric measurements has been based on physical understanding of radiative transfer, particles and the environment that these particles inhabit. For decades, physically-based methods have produced a suite of highly useful products. However, physically-based methods work best when their assumptions are accurate, and tend to fail in situations where the real world and retrieval assumptions do not match well. Especially difficult for aerosol retrieval algorithms is the separation of aerosol from clouds, identifying the type of aerosol from space and parameterizing the surface reflectance beneath the aerosol layers. In this project, a group with experience in physically-based aerosol remote sensing wants to explore Machine Learning (ML) or other advanced computation techniques with a student experienced in Data Science and/or ML. Possible projects might involve applying ML to one component of the retrieval, such as separating aerosols from clouds, or detecting aerosol types from multispectral and/or multi-temporal satellite imagery.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - Joint Polar Satellite System Table Top Model
description:
JPSS is an Earth focused satellite that contributes 85% of the data that informs the weather forecast but also has other applications for climate, ocean health, agriculture, ozone, disaster management and aviation. The JPSS satellites each have multiple instruments on board. This project would challenge the student to work with JPSS engineers to learn how the satellite's individual instruments work and create a scaled table top model that could be used for outreach to teach the community about JPSS. Students will work with a team of mentors from across JPSS and can apply their creativity and skills to create the model. 

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD.

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - AR-VR for Science and Engineering
description:
Interns will be doing a variety of tasks related to developing augmented reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR) applications for science and engineering. We are developing a range of AR/VR software applications that benefit the scientists and engineers at NASA. They target all NASA science domains (Earth Science, Planetary Science, Astrophysics, Heliophysics), Exploration, and Engineering. The ideal candidate is a combination programmer/3D artist, combining the ability to create or improve 3D content as well as programming their behavior and user interactions. Previous experience developing with Unity (C#) and Unreal (C++, Blueprints) is highly desired. Experience with Blender, Substance Painter, or other 3D software is a plus.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD.

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Wallops - Launch Range Ground Operations
description:
The Ground Operations Summer opportunity will support a variety of spaceflight missions at NASA Wallops Flight Facility (WFF) Launch Range. Ground Operations focuses on ground systems operation and maintenance used in the processing of spacecraft and launch vehicles. Students will learn about fluid commodities used in spacecraft propulsion, how to operate the systems delivering these commodities, and how to certify these commodities. This will give students exposure across many STEM disciples, including mechanical, chemical, and electrical engineering, and analytical chemistry. Students will participate in a hands-on learning experience and will work in a variety of environments (indoor, outdoor, laboratory, cleanrooms, control centers, etc.). Classroom safety training for pneumatic, propellant, cryogenic, and life support systems will also be offered. Students will be expected to demonstrate professionalism across diverse work settings and groups. By the completion of the project, students will have a basic understanding of a NASA spaceflight program lifecycle, tradeoffs between different launch vehicles, launch site vehicle and payload integration processes, system engineering, and day-of-launch operations.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of the Wallops Flight Facility in Wallops Island, VA.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - Supply Chain Quality
description:
The Supply Chain Quality participant will be responsible for assisting the GSFC Supply Chain Quality team in meeting the Safety & Mission Assurance (SMA) Directorate’s Supply Chain Risk Management (SCRM) objectives. This individual will have the opportunity to be a part of the daily Supply Chain Quality management activities, supplier research and analysis, including reporting, supplier data analytics, and supplier management.

SUMMARY OF KEY RESPONSIBILITIES:
• Participate in regular supply chain team planning meetings.
• Assist/Support Supply Chain Quality Management activities on a daily basis.
• Assist in development of Supply Chain Quality/Risk Management Web pages and content (e.g. supply chain team information, project resources, etc.)
• Access and navigate Meta/Supply Chain Insight Central (SCIC) Supply database, tracking, reporting, and data analytics , and other applications in support of Supply Chain Quality Team activities.
• Assist in the research, analysis, and generating reports to provide insight into the management, operations, availability and performance of current / potential suppliers for GSFC projects and associated concerns, and supply chain risks and issues.
• Perform data collection, spreadsheet creation, and data analysis, and develop supplier related data dashboards.
• Contribute to process and procedure documents for critical supply chain functions.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - Aerosol Satellite Retrieval using Hybrid Approach
description:
Project Objective:
This project focuses on combining machine learning (ML) with traditional satellite aerosol retrieval techniques to enhance the accuracy, reliability, and applicability of satellite aerosol products. By integrating the strengths of both approaches, the goal is to address key challenges in aerosol retrieval, including data uncertainty, model assumptions, aerosol subtype detection, and retrievals in difficult environments.

Project Scope:
The student will work on developing hybrid methodologies that leverage ML while retaining the physical principal of traditional aerosol retrieval methods. The areas of focus include:

Quantifying Data Uncertainty:
Enhancing uncertainty characterization by integrating ML models with traditional uncertainty estimation frameworks, providing robust error metrics for pixel level satellite-derived aerosol data.

Refining Aerosol Model Assumptions:
Combining ML-driven insights with traditional categorizing techniques to refine assumptions about aerosol properties such as size distribution, refractive index, and vertical profiles, resulting in more accurate retrievals.

Improving Aerosol Subtype Detection:
Utilizing ML classification techniques alongside traditional optical property analysis to enhance the detection and differentiation of aerosol subtypes (e.g., dust and smoke) using combined passive and active satellite observations.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - Dragonfly Support
description:
The Dragonfly mission to Saturn's Moon Titan will carry a mass spectrometer to measure surface composition. The instrument is currently in development at Goddard Space Flight Center, and will begin it's integration and test (I&T) process soon. name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - Prototyping Large Language ESDIS
description:
Some years ago, Earthdata Search (EDSC) deprecated its Natural Language Processing (NLP) due to inaccuracies in the results of the COTS products used. NASA SMD has recently lamented the lack of NLP capabilities in EDSC and the Common Metadata Repository (CMR). The ability to provide a ChatGPT-like user interface to the CMR or Earthdata as a whole would greatly aid the discovery of NASA earth science data. A prototype/proof of concept activity could be used as a springboard for providing such a capability. We could learn from and collaborate with the NASA Copilot team on behalf of ESDIS to leverage knowledge that could improve earth science data discovery.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - Goddard  NASA Communications and Engagement
description:
NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center (GSFC) Office of Communications is seeking a motivated high school student to support public engagement efforts and visitor center activities. This opportunity provides an exciting opportunity to contribute to NASA’s mission by helping inform and inspire the public, VIP visitors, and special guests through tours, presentations, and hands-on engagement.

Key Responsibilities:
-Assist with VIP visits and high-profile tours, including preparing materials, coordinating logistics, and supporting NASA staff.
-Work at the Goddard Visitor Center, engaging with the public, answering questions, and helping facilitate interactive exhibits and educational experiences.
-Support the planning and execution of public engagement events, both on-site and virtual, including panel discussions, STEM outreach, and interactive demonstrations.
-Help prepare presentations, tour scripts, and outreach materials for internal and external visitors.
-Assist in coordinating internal and external engagement activities, such as employee engagement events, community outreach, and educational programming.
-Participate in team meetings and brainstorming sessions, providing ideas and logistical support for visitor experiences and engagement initiatives.
-Other duties as assigned to support the mission of the Office of Communications.

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - Optical Ray Trace Modeling
description:
Every Agency & Corporation that has designed or simulated radiometric phenomena, thermal self-emissions or optical systems/instruments has required Bidirectional Scatter Distribution Functions (BSDF) of many, many types of optomechanical surfaces (which vary greatly according to materials, coatings, even contamination and machining methods) in non-sequential ray trace modeling.

The data comes in many forms from vendors, test facilities or internally; by measurement, test data and sometimes published charts. These BSDF data products must be converted to a format that can be input into FRED Optical Analysis Software or Zemax Optics Studio (ZOS) and then verified by simulating an ideal computer-based scatterometer making measurements from a representative sample coupon. Archiving data in this usable form will save a good deal of time and money on future programs requiring stray light, illumination, imaging and radiometric analyses.

This effort already has a good deal of available data which a student with Python/Matlab skills could process to render the data in a useable format for FRED/ZOS. I've already constructed a simulation of a scatterometer (e.g. such as one built by The Scatter Works (Bozeman, MT) or CASI (Tuscon, AZ)) which the student may use to verify the conversion and compare with original measurement(s). SolidWorks CAD modeling could be utilized as well.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD.

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - ML/AI for GEOS Chemistry Climate Model
description:
This project aims to provide opportunities for interested students to learn about the GEOS Chemistry Climate Model (GEOSCCM), perform existing model output data analysis to understand atmospheric composition for the 21st century, and to use Machine Learning/Artificial Intelligence (ML/AI) to improve and optimize GEOSCCM simulation speed. Ozone is one of the most important trace gases in our atmosphere. It acts as an invisible shield and protects us from harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun. Ozone near the surface is a pollutant that affects air quality. Accurate representation of ozone and its chemistry using 3-Dimensional atmospheric chemistry model has important implications for composition, climate, and surface air quality. The GEOSCCM is NASA’s state-of-the-art model designed to simulate ozone and the potential feedbacks between the atmosphere’s composition and the state of the climate in the 21st century. 

Preferences will be given to candidates that are familiar with Machine Learning/Artificial Intelligence, Python, IDL or similar graphic analysis software, and Jupyter Notebook and cloud computing.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD.

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - Simulation Environment for Mobile Robots
description:
A MATLAB application will be developed for kinematic and dynamic analysis of mobile robots focusing on autonomous path planning and control. Autonomous mobile robots are being introduced in many space applications, including planetary sample collection and surface exploration. In the last several years, simulations became an important part of hardware development in the field of robotics and reinforcement learning (RL). Modern RL methods show incredible results with virtual robot models learning to avoid obstacles while exploring unknown terrains. Many of these test cases describe theoretical fields of application and are not yet used in a real environment. RL can learn from experiences and apply the learned knowledge to real life problems. However, the acquisition of training data for RL algorithms is one of the most challenging tasks. The goal of this project is to develop a reliable simulation environment with physical robot models to facilitate quicker and realistic RL algorithm development.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - Analysis of Space Radiation Environment
description:
Our space is not a perfect vacuum but filled with high-energy ions and electrons. The intensities of these energetic particles define our space radiation environment. The escalation of energetic particles in space has hazardous effects on satellites and astronauts. It thus motivates the goal of this project to understand the radiation environment surrounding a space object, such as the International Space Station (ISS), how the radiation varies with the location of the satellite and with activities on the Sun. To achieve the project goal, students will analyze data from particle detectors on the ISS, Van Allen Probes and other satellites. Students are expected to download, visualize the data in various formats and perform analysis to identify factors controlling the radiation intensity. Ground-based data may be studied as well, e.g., magnetometer measurements.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - Plasma Wave Dynamics
description:
The proposed project aims to investigate the properties and spatial distribution of plasma waves observed simultaneously at different magnetic local times (MLT) using data from the Van Allen Probes mission. This twin-spacecraft mission provided unprecedented in situ observations of the Earth's radiation belts, enabling a comprehensive study of wave-particle interactions. Waves such as electromagnetic ion cyclotron (EMIC) waves, whistler-mode chorus, and ultra-low-frequency(ULF) waves play crucial roles in the dynamics of energetic particles, including their acceleration, transport, and precipitation. However, the generation, propagation, and effects of these waves often exhibit significant local time asymmetries due to variations in magnetospheric conditions, such as plasma density, geomagnetic field strength, and solar wind driving.

By leveraging the Van Allen Probes' spatially separated orbits, this project will analyze wave activity simultaneously across two different local time sectors. Key objectives include characterizing the frequency, amplitude, and polarization of the observed waves and identifying the conditions under which specific wave types dominate in different MLT regions. For example, EMIC waves are often stronger in the dusk-to-midnight sector, while whistler-mode chorus waves are prevalent in the dawn region. The project will explore how these waves evolve during quiet and geomagnetically disturbed intervals and their coupling with particle populations. The outcomes will enhance our understanding of radiation belt dynamics, wave-particle interactions, and magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling, providing critical insights for space weather prediction and mitigation strategies. This project aligns with advancing our knowledge of fundamental plasma processes in the near-Earth space environment.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - Downstream task development and evaluation
description:
Foundation model is the core of ChatGPT and other generative machine learning models. However, it's advantage over traditional deep learning (DL) models hasn't been extensively studied in NASA remote sensing data domain. For this position, the selected candidate is expected to develop benchmark DL models for atmosphere related downstream tasks of an existing foundation model (SatVision-TOA), and evaluate/compare to understand whether SatVision-TOA model can bring extra benfits. The selected candidate will work with frontier ML experts at NASA Goddard and contribute to frontier science. The incumbent is expected to actively attend weekly discussions and provides progress updates. The candidate should have ML background. Some knowledge or experience with the transformer model is a plus.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - Machine Learning Platform Development
description:
This project focuses on the development of a machine learning (ML) platform designed to help scientists learn and apply ML techniques to their specific areas of interest. The primary task will involve building an image classification model using the MNIST database, guiding users through the fundamental steps of ML. This includes tasks such as preprocessing data to ensure it is clean and ready for analysis, designing and training a neural network using tools like TensorFlow or PyTorch, fine-tuning parameters to optimize model performance, and evaluating the model’s accuracy. You may also have the opportunity to create additional examples to showcase the flexibility of ML techniques, helping users explore topics like data augmentation, neural network design, and practical strategies for analyzing model performance.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - Analysis of Roman Telescope Image Data
description:
Join Roman Space Telescope I&T Science Data Processing team and work on an AI/ML data processing project. This project involves analyzing detector images collected during the mission I&T phase and validates the system requirements. You will process large datasets using Python libraries like NumPy and Pandas, train an ML model using PyTorch to predict detector behavior, and visualize the results using Matplotlib. This project offers a unique opportunity for high school students to gain hands-on experience in data analysis and machine learning. You will work closely with experienced software developers, learn from them, and contribute to the launch of Roman Space Telescope.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - Long Range  Transport of Air Pollution
description:
Air pollutants such as nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and sulfur dioxide (SO2) adversely affect air quality, public health, and the ecosystems. They are largely emitted from human activities such as power generation and transportation (and from volcanoes, in the case of SO2). While these air pollutants are typically short-lived, with a lifetime of just hours to days in the atmosphere, they can travel over thousands of kilometers under favorable meteorological conditions. This process, referred to as long-range transport, can turn air pollution from a local phenomenon into a global environmental issue. NASA’s earth observing satellites provide global observations of several air pollutants including NO2 and SO2, thus offering opportunities to monitor, track, and assess the impact of long-range transport.

The student in this project will use NASA satellite data to study long-range transport of air pollution. The focus will be on a cluster of large power plants in South Africa that is a known major source of NO2 and SO2. The intern will use and develop computer software to visualize NO2 and SO2 data from satellites and other relevant datasets, identify and track long-range transport events, and conduct statistical analysis on the identified events. The student will also explore machine learning based techniques to automate the detection and tracking of such events. During the project, the student can expect to work with and receive guidance from scientists who are experienced in satellite remote sensing, data analysis, and machine learning.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - Occupational Health - Industrial Hygiene
description:
The GSFC Industrial Hygiene team functions to recognize, evaluate, and control workplace health hazards.  This project within GSFC Industrial Hygiene will involve researching and documenting probability of failure and anticipated release rates of components and instruments of cryogenic systems and asphyxiant gas systems so that proper levels of protections and controls are designated to users of liquid and gaseous systems that could produce an oxygen deficient atmosphere in the event of a leak, malfunction, or release.  Calculations will be conducted for operations and systems to determine oxygen deficiency classifications.  Various other duties will be performed as follows: Entering workplace health survey information and equipment calibration documents into the health information system; examining health information system to gather general statistics, examining web-based training feedback questionnaires and determining metrics based on responses; extracting lists of personnel from data system; performing excel functions to compare personnel lists to training lists; conducting trend analysis of workplace exposures; and possibly industrial hygiene field work involving indoor air quality and ventilation.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Wallops - Goddard Sustainability & Energy Program
description:
Selected students will support the Goddard Sustainability, Energy & Water Programs at the Wallops campus. The project primarily covers support to facilities and mission assets (e.g., rocket, balloon and UAV systems, clean rooms, research labs, utility systems). 

Potential work performed to include data collection and analysis, engineering research, drawing review, meters and site surveys, equipping/labeling (GOMAR) utility meter systems, identifying Interference, calculating circular economy of products, energy and water conservation, environmental engineering, pollution prevention and recycling strategies, climate change adaptation, and strategic planning,  Projects planned include identifying/documenting Goddard sustainable buildings, retro-commissioning, Envision sustainability certification of the WFF Causeway Bridge Replacement Project, tracking carbon emissions and footprint reductions through development of public transit/carpool plans, and improving sustainability program outreach and awareness through newsletter articles, website development, and updates.  

Skills needed include writing, communication, and presentation skills.

Work performed will develop the students analytical capabilities, familiarity with daily engineering work, and communication skills through frequent interaction with NASA engineers, scientists and program managers. The data collected will provide crucial information enabling Goddard to meet NASA's sustainability goals.


Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Wallops Flight Facility in Wallops Island, VA.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

name: NASA: Space Club @ GSFC Greenbelt - LISA Laser System Component Test Optimization
description:
GSFC is developing the Laser System (LS) for the LISA Mission.  The Laser System consists of many electro-optic components that need to be tested and characterized.  The polarization extinction ratio (PER) is one of the critical performance parameters that is measured during the component testing.  This project is to study and learn the basics of PER measurements for electro-optic component testing, and develop test software using Phyton or Labview to automate the test.

Eligible applicants for this project must reside within 50 miles of Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, MD

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
